title: Auditing WiseTech's Christine Holman departure
text:
One high-ranking ingredient of Stevenson-Yang’s short thesis is that “on Tuesday, Christine Holman, who joined the board only 10 months ago, in December 2018, and is chair of the Audit and Risk Management Committee, resigned.”

To be sure, WiseTech’s handling of Holman’s departure was torturous. On Tuesday, she was “retiring from the board… at the 2019 annual general meeting in November” – November 19 to be particular.

But then on Friday, the following addendum: “WiseTech Global confirms that in line with the previous announcement of non-executive director Christine Holman’s intention to retire and not seek election at the 2019 AGM, Christine’s resignation is effective from today.” Which was simply not in line with the previous announcement.

Compare this to Corporate Travel’s former chairman Tony Bellas, who deferred his scheduled retirement in October last year to assist in responding to VGI Partners’ short attack. In nearly identical circumstances, Holman has brought hers forward.

But is this a red flag, or just Christine being Christine?

Cast your mind back to August 15, 2017, when enterprise telco Vocus – at the time with KKR and Affinity in its data room, both yet to bail – announced the appointment of Holman as a director (effective August 24). “Christine will join the audit committee and will sit on the board of [Vocus subsidiary] ASC International Group.”

That was short-lived; a reverse David Crawford, if you will. “Christine Holman has today resigned as a non-executive director, effective immediately,” Vocus advised the ASX on November 13 of the same year. “Chairman Vaughan Bowen said, ‘we thank Christine for her contribution to the company during her time as a director and wish her all the best.’” Her contribution? In just 81 days, her enlightened perspective was irrevocably forged in the corporation’s DNA?

Holman remains a director of vitamin house Blackmores, which she joined in April, and building products group CSR (a personal best, with her stint there having now ticked over three years). Apologies to Paul McCartney, but when they find themselves in times of trouble, she will flee...

WiseTech shares will resume trading on Monday.
description: Is the departure of WiseTech's audit committee chair really a red flag, or just Christine Holman being Christine Holman?
